reviewText: The '07 release of the psychological drama `The Number 23' is a mixed bag that attempts to weave together the details of the life of seemingly average guy Walter Sparrow (Jim Carrey) by moving back and forth between two worlds of contradictory information. One world is a surreal, almost hallucinogenic realm comprised of fragmentary dream images, long forgotten memories and the ongoing storyline of a rather obscure self-published book Walter's reading. This interior world is placed in juxtaposition to the more accessible day to day details of his rather mundane life as a husband, father and canine control officer (dog catcher).Some segments of the film are quite good, others not so well. The pace is also a little too slow and the plot too predictable to really hold your attention in the manner hoped for. I found myself comparing both the cinematic style of the film and the storyline with other films that `The Number 23' must have surely borrowed from. I see a lot of `Sin City' in its dark and shadowy artistic style and narrative and the plot borrows heavily from `The Haunted Strangler' an old Boris Karloff film from the late fifties. I assume that if I'm thinking of other films while watching this one something must be wrong.My Rating: It could have been a lot better but it's worth a watch. Unfortunately once is enough for me, -3 Stars-.

William S. Burroughs, the Beat author of Naked Lunch, The Wild Boys, and The Nova Express, also came to believe that the number 23 held mystical significance after encountering it during significant moments in his life. reviewText: I feel that this psychological mind bend of a film has garnered a bit of undeserved criticism. While "The Number 23" won't appeal to everyone, it is still an intricate and freaky look into a man's numeral obsession.Jim Carrey stars as Walter -- a bored dog catcher who get's sucked into an obsession with the number 23 after his wife gives him a book on his birthday (one in which the number 23 plays a vital role in the unhinging of it's characters). Walter drifts back and forth between his real life and growing obsession, and the story detailed with the blood red novel about a bad-boy detective and his quest to understand the curse of the number 23.As we've seen him do in films likeThe Truman Show (Special Collector's Edition)andThe Majestic, Jim Carrey stretches his acting chops by completely abandoning his stereotypical funny man role, and digging deep into a slightly more serious, and in this case quite sinister role. When we see one of the greatest comedic talents in a completely twisted and dark film, it challenges us to try to forget our own biases about Carrey, and try to take him seriously in this oddity of a character. I think that Carrey pulled it off beautifully, but I know there are others who would disagree with me.Weird can be good. If a film is going to do "weird", it's important to do it right, otherwise it will just come off as unentertainingly bizarre and dull. The cinematography in this movie is incredible. The camera angles and colors uniquely work together to pull the viewer into Walter's demented mind as he visualizes himself experiencing the life of this mysterious Detective and the obsession with the number 23.The 23 enigma is a real occurence. Many of it's examples are illustrated in the film. However, it's also a fact that if you're looking hard enough for something, such as the repitition of a number, then you're bound to find it. Some examples of the odd recurrence of the number 23 include:**William Shakespeare was born on the 23rd, and died on the 23rd.**Julius Cesaer was stabbed 23 times.**The Titanic sank on April 15, 1912. April is the 4th month, which means 4+1+5+1+9+1+2= 23**The Earth revolves on an axis tilted at an angle of 23.5 (23 is right there in the number, and 5 is simply 2+3).** I wrote this review on the 23rd of July. (...okay, so that last one isn't really relevant to this movie, but you get the idea...)These and many other examples are given. A fun fact for this movie would be that Jim Carrey himself actually has a fascination with the 23 enigma. While he was explaining it to a friend one day, his friend laughed and told him that he had just read a new script called the Number 23, and that it was about exactly what Jim was describing. Jim eagerly asked to read the script, and signed on to do the film shortly after.Some people don't feel that Jim Carrey was the right choice for the role. I think they are wrong. I found him engaging, and he was well complimented by the performance of Virginia Madsen as his wife (even though Elizabeth Shue was originally set to do the role, she had to back out after she became pregnant shortly after agreeing to do the film).When you hit "play" on the DVD, it will give you the option of watching the rated R theatrical version, or the extended unrated version. The main difference between the two is that the unrated version has more sex scenes in it. If you don't like overly gratuitous sex scenes, then go ahead and watch the rated R version. I personally recommend the unrated version.Bottom line, it's worth a try. It's weird, it's bizarre, it's cooky, and it's a real mind trip...but it's a lot of fun in the process.

reviewText: A willing viewer of Joel Schumacher's "The Number 23" will discover that watching it has some interesting side effects. In my case, I began thinking about how twenty-three is prevalent in my life: I'm currently twenty-three years old; there are twenty-three typed characters when "Chris Pandolfi" is combined with "Amazon.com." A coincidence, I'm sure, but doesn't it make you wonder? In terms of the film itself, I became perceptive to certain numbers that were casually presented throughout; an outside shot of a bookstore shows its address as being 599. Add those numbers together and see what you get.I'm having fun with this, but in all seriousness, "The Number 23" is a fascinating psychological thriller, purposely constructed as a mind game for the audience to participate in. We're immediately introduced to animal control officer Walter Sparrow (Jim Carrey) on his birthday, which just happens to fall on February third (2/3). Most of his day is incredibly boring; he just sits in his van drinking coffee, waiting for a loose animal to run by. After hours of waiting, he's asked to remove a mixed bulldog from the back of a Chinese restaurant. It seems to regard him with contempt, which is probably why it bites him and runs off. He then chases it to a local cemetery. While he doesn't manage to catch it, he does notice that it rests in front of a specific tombstone.This incident forces Walter to be late in meeting his wife, Agatha (Virginia Madsen), outside of a used book shop. But no worries; she passes the time by reading an unpublished manuscript. By the time Walter arrives, she decides to give it to her husband as a kind of late birthday present. It's called "The Number 23," a novel of paranoia written by the obscure Topsy Krett. The foreword warns that if characters and circumstances seem even remotely familiar to the reader, then it's best to not continue the story. Reverse psychology is at work, here; Krett is practically daring the reader to turn to the first page and find out why such a warning was written in the first place. Like any curious reader would do, Walter plunges directly into the manuscript.As he begins reading, he envisions himself as the main character, nicknamed Fingerling. The story is quite similar to that of a pulp detective novel, and it unfolds in sequences so stylized that they almost come off as campy. The world in Krett's novel is dripping with atmosphere: every visual makes use of a saturated color scheme; every character is mysterious, moody, sensuous, and sinister; every descriptive paragraph and line of dialogue is borderline cliche. It told the story of a detective on the case of suicidal blonde woman. She was consumed by the number twenty-three, which seemed to mirror every aspect of her life. It was both fun and baffling to watch these sequences: on the one hand, they effectively reinterpret reality as a living comic book; on the other hand, they seemed too over the top to do justice to the mystery and paranoia that soon take hold of Walter.This is because--despite the specific details being different--he immediately notices how eerily similar the book is to his own life. Fingerling tracks down felons and victims, Walter tracks stray animals. Both Fingerling and Walter collected detective magazines as kids. Both their futures were perfectly envisioned by demanding fathers. Most importantly, both are becoming obsessed with the number twenty-three, so much so that they continually get dark visions. Fingerling keeps having nightmares of murdering his girlfriend, a sultry Italian named Fabrizia (also played by Virginia Madsen). Walter eventually has the same nightmares about Agatha, and it rightfully makes him question how sane a person he really is. "You'd never hurt me," Agatha tells him reassuringly. She then goes to kiss Walter, only to hear him reply, "How do you know?"There's some clever manipulation going on here, especially in terms of the manuscript itself. On every twenty-third page, Walter circles every twenty-third word, which reveal a hidden message. The writer, whoever he is, is obviously trying to send a message. To who and about what, Walter has yet to discover. But he gets closer when he learns of a woman named Laura Tollins, who was murdered fifteen years earlier. Not only was her body never found, the man serving time for her murder is also adamantly denying any wrongdoing. If he's telling the truth, then that means her killer is still roaming the streets.How does this connect with Krett and his manuscript? What, if anything, does the number twenty-three actually represent? Is the manuscript, in fact, a warped reflection of Walter Sparrow's life? Why does the mixed bulldog keep reappearing? Why is the twenty-third chapter missing from the end of the manuscript? This is a list of questions for you to consider when watching this movie. I can assure you that all of them will be answered. What I cannot assure you is that you'll be satisfied with the answers. While the film's final revelations aren't particularly bad, I still found them somewhat disappointing. For a film of considerable craft, the ending seemed a little too simplistic and formulaic. Nonetheless, I'm going to recommend "The Number 23," if not for the engaging mystery, then for the sheer delight in watching Jim Carrey perform in a dramatic role. I'll also recommend it for it's clever manipulation of numbers. After all, it was released on February 23 for a reason.

reviewText: Joel Schumacher has always been the kind of filmmaker that we love to bash because he just makes it so easy. Sure now and then he makes something surprising such as Tigerland or Phone Booth but by and large he's always been extremely unreliable at making good movies. And let's not forget the debacle that was the Batman films he did. Now, he sets his sights on the idea that patterns and numbers hold mystical significance and that we're surrounded by eerie coincidences. Or you know, it's just really silly stuff.Walter Sparrow is a dog catcher who comes across a book his wife found called "the Number 23". The wife doesn't seem too interested but when he starts reading, he starts to get drawn into the story of detective Fingerling, who is becoming increasingly obsessed with the frequent occurences of the number 23 in dates, names and color shades. Interestingly, many of the things written in the book match Walter's life and with the help of his wife Agatha and son Robin, he tries to figure out the mystery of the number.The film's goal is to make you afraid of strange coincidences and recurring appearances of the number 23. So right there you have to wonder "can a number really freak me out?" Well, probably not since it's played with deadpan seriousness that you almost can imagine actors flubbing their lines because of how silly it sounds. One scene involving a dog and Walter's decision to "take care of the problem" is so hilarious, it's hard to take the film seriously. Not to mention the frequent decodings of everything equalling 23 is kind of absurd and if you were to play the drinking game, you'd probably never put your bottle down. Granted, Schumacher on occasion can create interesting visuals, such as a long shot involving Fingerling's younger years or a rotating camera around a room that's magically filling up with scribblings, but it's all for naught as the story itself is so bad that the visuals merely feel like the best thing going rather than enhancing anything.Acting-wise, we're pretty much in the same ballpark. Proving himself as a dramatic actor already with the Truman Show and Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind, here he seems to be trying a bit too hard where he gets super excited about anything involving the number or he says things in a really hushed tone. Only one I really liked was Virginia Madsen even though her character does rather dumb things. No woman I know would follow her husband that far since they'd probably just turn the guy in and deal with it all with her husband behind bars.The Number 23 is one of those films released on DVD that you'd probably rent simply because you can't think of anything else to watch. reviewText: Walter Sparrow lives a normal life. He seems a little bored with his job as a dog catcher, but happy nevertheless. The movie begins with him being talked into trying to catch a stray dog just minutes before he's about to get off work for the day. He's supposed to meet his wife as soon as he gets off work since it's his birthday. So everything seems to be in order until the dog bites him and he ends up running late. Meanwhile his wife works at a cake shop and is waiting for her husband to meet her there. While she's waiting for him, a book catches her eye in the store next door. The dog ends up getting away from him and he leaves empty handed. He finally arrives and is relieved to see that his wife is still there. She ends up buying the book for him as a present even though he's a little skeptical about it at first. Once he starts reading it, however, he starts becoming obsessed with the number 23 and is convinced that everything that has ever happened in his life relates to that number. Once he starts reading the book, the movie jumps back in forth between reality and the story. Once we've established we're in the story, Walter Sparrow becomes Fingerling, the detective. He thinks the book is written specifically for him and is basically a retelling of his life. He spends the rest of the film trying to figure out the mystery of who the author really is.The whole thing that drew me to this movie was Jim Carrey being in a horror movie. I probably wouldn't have been half as interested if he wasn't in it. I immediately became less enthused when I realized who Joel Schumacher was and what other movies he had directed. For those who don't know, he's the director of films like Batman Forever, Batman and Robin, and 8MM. A big deal was made about him and Jim Carrey reuniting for The Number 23. I can't really say that it was a reunion that everyone was looking forward to or one that paid off in the end.When I first saw the trailer, I was excited as hell to see this movie. I thought that it looked great and couldn't wait to see it. It was a discussion with a guy at work that really brought the idea of the movie into a new light. He was saying that it looked stupid and that it had one of the worst ideas for a movie he'd ever heard. While he was explaining it to someone else at work, I realized how ridiculous the movie really sounded. I just hadn't really thought about how it would sound out loud. Jim Carrey was really the sole purpose I wanted to see this movie. I really enjoyed his more serious roles like the ones in The Majestic and Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind. Why would I feel any different about this film?Right away, in the first few minutes of the film, people are going to compare Jim Carrey's actions to another role. A certain pet detective. I can't really blame them, especially after he continues to tell the dog a story while he's trying to catch it. There were certain things like that in the film that made things humorous when they probably weren't meant to be. He said something along the lines of, "I rest my case, your honor," that just reminded me of Liar, Liar. I couldn't help but laugh. Some of the dialogue that's exchanged in the last act of the film didn't make things much better. I think I was waiting for the point in the film for Jim Carrey to just go absolutely insane where he could go over the top and just be crazy. It never really came though. He does go crazy and he does it well, but it just wasn't what I was expecting. The other thing I wasn't happy with was the "twist" of the film. It made the entire film a waste of time. There were several things left unanswered, as well. Unless there's a sequel, we'll never get those answers. We can only assume.In the end, I was honestly just disappointed with the film. I had heard so many bad reviews, but didn't want to believe them. I went into this wanting to like this film, but I guess I went in with higher expectations than I originally intended. I didn't hate the film, but I didn't like it either. I really disliked the twist, but other than that the movie did have its moments. I'd recommend waiting for it to come out on DVD before you see it, so you don't walk away unsatisfied like I did. Jim Carrey did a pretty good job in his first horror movie, but it seems like it could have been so much better. After seeing this, I think he should consider either staying away from the horror genre or staying away from Joel Schumacher.Rating: 5/10

reviewText: When Agatha Sparrow (Virginia Madsen) has an extra moment at a book store while waiting for her husband Walter (Jim Carrey), she picks up a book about the number 23.  Written by Topsy Kretts (I would have gone with something like Drew Peacock or Jacques Strap), it's about loose numerology, and connections between statistics that soon consume Walter's life.  Before making it through more than the first few chapters, he realizes that all the important numbers in his life, his important dates, his address, his zip code, his in-seam (just kidding), and his IQ (not kidding) can all be easily manipulated to some variation of the number 23.  Paranoia ensues.Jim Carrey's dual-performance as Walter, and Fingerling, the sociopath detective from the book causing the paranoia, is masterful.  Carrey shows his range as an actor, distancing himself from the rubber-faced contortionist act that made him a superstar.  And Virginia Madsen as a cleavage-displaying, sex-craved Fabrizia, a woman into bondage, sadomasochism, and rape fantasies is equally jaw dropping.  In fact, combining her character with the cameo by Rhona Mitra makes me wish there were a sequel.Portions of the cinematography are similarly ingenious.  There are extreme color contrasts, with blacks darker than an eclipse battling bleached alabaster whites for the viewer's focus.  The combination reminded me of aspects from Sin City.Finally, the ending is interesting but a little predictable.  If one allows themselves to delve into the story, it's quite easy to ignore the foreshadowing.  For those who enjoy pointing out how a magician does something more than enjoying the magic, you may hate the ending.As far as the actual point of the movie, well, that's pretty stupid.  Forgive me, but it just doesn't add up.  Jim Carey was born on Jan 17.  If January is the number 1, and you add it to 17, there doesn't seem to be anything mysterious going on; it's only 18.  But if you add the 5 times I rolled my eyes during the number theory explanations, wait, THAT'S 23!!  What I learned from the movie are two terms I found to describe the plot.  The first is apophenia, the experience of seeing patterns or connections in random or meaningless data.  The second is known as the Texas sharpshooter fallacy.  Basically, the idea comes from the idea of someone shooting several rounds into the broadside of a barn, and THEN painting a target in such a fashion to make it appear that the shots were on target.  In other words, the conclusions are artificial.Then again, I was born in 1976 (1+9+7+6=23)...
summary: Stats never lie, but liars use stats

reviewText: Maybe it was to be expected that Schumacher, who hasn't really made a very satisfying film since the mid 90s, would gravitate to material like this that would at least allow him some time to exercise his 'weird' directorial chops. And really, there is some potential in this as well; Carrey's dog-catcher protagonist is given a book on his birthday (which is on 2/3) called the Number 23, which deals with a sax-playing detective with a dark past who gets involved with an even darker, more sadistic woman (Virginia Madsen, who also plays the 'real-world' wife of Carrey's character, as he envisions it as he reads it anyway), and the sadism and murder and madness that ensues. If there was just a straight adaptation of the book AS the movie, or if the archetypal figures that lay in this pulpy world inspired in part by serial novels were just put forward simply without the number symbolism, it would be a much more intriguing movie. Especially because said 'imagined' scenes showing what happens in the book are shot in a perfectly abstract style, where even in the choppy edit parts there's still a vicious vision going on. These sparks indicate that there could be some talent in the writer and filmmaker.As for Carrey, he seems to be just going through his motions for what he can do as an actor (as with Madsen, up to a point), but it's not enough to stop what happens with the script, which at times seems to be going at lengths to continue that montage in Pee Wee's Big Adventure when Pee-Wee sees all the bikes going by when his is gone. Soon Carrey's "every-man" sees it everywhere, with numbers adding up, the combinations endless, and it all leading to what ends up being so predictable I wouldn't dare spoil it not because it's very important but just to not insult your intelligence reading this. Just let it be known that Phillips decides to take that easy-route of the main character really having to face head-on everything that he's encountered so far and then re-contemplate everything in his entire life. This, which makes up the last fifteen minutes, is excruciating in the length of the exposition, with all the answers spoon-fed to the audience so that nothing is left questioned about who this man really is or what he's done. It compounds what has already gone on with the pretentious obsessive qualities, of it being about the 'trick' instead of it being more interesting about characters (the very last scene also made me shake my head and do all but throw a pillow at the screen)."The number 23" it's a pretty dense entry in the careers of both actor and director, which also happens to include a supporting character of a dog named Ned, Bud Cort in the thankless role, and lots of big-budget attention paid to the grungy details of what is under a happy existence to reveal the wretched skeletons in the closet (or rather under a stone in a park). reviewText: Huh?  That was the feeling I was left with after watching the number 23, an absurd attempt at a thriller.  Not because the math was over my head, but because I'm continually boggled by how much energy, money, and time can go into producing films that make absolutely no sense and fail to entertain.  The first fatal flaw is that the film is really about Walter Sparrow (Jim Carrey) reading a book.  Before the movie itself has engaged the audience, the viewer is forced to watch Walter obsessively reading.  I couldn't help but wonder, why not just make the book the movie, and get rid of watching someone reading a book which becomes the movie?  Oh, because that would have made it impossible to shoot half the film like a ridiculous eighties music video to signal to the viewer that they are watching the book and not the movie itself.  While in the "book", Walter wears floor length leather jackets and broods in smoky lighting with slicked back hair while a bleach blond bimbo is murdered in her bed.  I kept expecting Rick Ocasek to pop out and start signing behind Walter, posturing in the exclusively white, black, and red movie set.  The book likewise enables the insertion of beyond gratuitous S and M sex scenes between Walter and his wife (Virginia Madsen), who is turned into a leather bound whore in the book.  While a movie about a book could have been an intellectual twist, the characters in the film are unable to utter more than the most banal comments about the book, like it was "creative".  Walter likewise proclaims to be against the concept of reading and putting someone else's lies and nonsense inside his head.  Can I really invest two hours watching a character that is anti- reading?The use of Carrey's comedic talents is forced, and his character comes off as one of those irritating mentally unstable people that cracks dumb jokes at anything and everything to avoid reality or truthfulness.  Virginia Madsen, the new "it" girl for playing everyone's bland film wife, is likewise irritating and one dimensional even when they slap a black wig on her and turn her into a sex crazed prostitute.To make matters worse, the DVD I rented forced me to watch the "infinifilm" version of the movie.  If (like me) you have never heard of this format - the infinifilm inserts large, blue pop ups on the screen every few minutes of the movie, with prompts to hit the return button to "learn more about the character" and other tidbits from the movie.  Have we become so ADHD as a culture that people no longer have the attention span to watch a movie without pop ups? The Hollywood rendition of "The Number 23" fails to connect with the mystery and resorts to mayhem, violence, and shock to derail what could have been a sly, psychological thriller.Sigmund Freud, Carl Jung, William Burroughs, Aleister Crowley, Robert Anton Wilson, and many other noted, great thinkers were ensnared by the spell of this number. So have many lesser known, but equally earnest seekers of truth. Jim Carrey, in the role of Walter Sparrow, seems like a cardboard cut-out of the authentic seekers who have attempted to solve the 23 enigma.Many have been swept up in the synchronicities associated around the number 23 as it manifests unexpectedly; more than a few become obsessed. If you look for 23, it's suddenly all around, traversing time from past to present. It might be the metal numbers on a power pole in your yard, the number of the garment inspector who left a slip in your new shirt's pocket, a child's birthday, or your change from the coffee shop.It may appear simply as shorthand for referring to our current president,"W," the 23rd letter of the alphabet, and it is in our DNA. And the number 23 is central to the plot in the popular TV show "Lost," and 23 showed in some fashion nearly every episode of "Star Trek the Next Generation" that I watched.This movie suggests that the number 23 has some secret control of Walter Sparrow's mind and actions, but the movie only scratches the surface, substituting violence for subtlety, stumbling over the historical perspective, and weaving out of control. The attempts to show how 23 is everywhere come across as a bit contrived at times, but do capture the mindset of those who become ensnared in obsessive thinking.Jim Carrey does take what is a quiet, internalized obsession for most star-crossed 23 conspirators and turn it into an external manifestation of fear, confusion, and madness. It's fun to watch his reactions to the web of 23s ensnaring him and to work out the codes that yield 23s as his character does the same.The movie, though, is a glorious mess of confusing plot strands, flashbacks, and twists, and provides scant understanding into why the characters choose one course of action or into what motivates most of the supporting cast to be part of the storyline.Visually, the tone and sets work with the theme--better than a convoluted plot that hints at the mystery of 23 without even suggesting what is at the heart of the 23 enigma.It's too bad that those who brought this concept to the silver screen did not do a better job at conveying the story of this number, but perhaps they were all puppets of a greater force. In other words, a documentary would have been much more engaging than this flawed fictional portrayal about the 23 enigma.
summary: Failed attempt to capture the subtle aspects of a great mystery

reviewText: Return, you say? Yes, he's done it before, in a movie that was falsely billed as a comedy and was instead far more disturbing than funny. He's done it in most of his movies, whether playing a pet detective, boy-in-a-media-bubble, cable guy, or dogcatcher. He's especially good here, and the movie--though it does drag at times--is everything it promised in the trailers.(This review has been posted by Marcus Damanda, author of the vampire book "Teeth: A Horror Fantasy.")

reviewText: THE NUMBER 23 is Jim Carrey's first venture out of the realm of wacky, Kramer-esque physical comedy and into serious acting. THE NUMBER 23 was skewered by some incredibly short sighted critics, who mercilessly laid waste to the film, and it ended up only racking in some $35 million in it's theatrical run.Granted, after the witnessing the corpse that was BATMAN AND ROBIN, having Joel Schumacher as your director probably won't do much to inspire and sort of positive reaction, but THE NUMBER 23 is actually an indication that Schumacher is back in the business of making movies that can be taken seriously.Dogcatcher Walter Sparrow (Jim Carrey), whose name begins and ends with the 23rd letter of the alphabet, receives and interesting gift for his birthday: a book called "The Number 23: A novel of Obsession" by Topsy Kretts. It revolves around borderline psychotic Detective Fingerling (also Jim Carrey) receiving what seems to be some kind of numerical obsession curse from a blonde suicide, who kills herself when her obsession with the number 23 becomes to much.Walter soon realizes that a significant portion of the events in the book correspond to his own life...and begins to fear that he is destined to follow Fingerling's fate of becoming a killer. Walter's wife Agatha (Virginia Madsen) dismisses the whole thing as sheer coincidence, but before long, Walter realizes that the events of the book also mirror an actual murder,and realizes that book is in fact, a masked confession by the murderer. As he becomes determined to discover who wrote the sel-fpublished and self-printed book, his quest eventually leads him to discover the dark secret of the author's true identity.THE NUMBER 23 is one of the most underrated movies I have ever seen. It's one of the most well-crafted murder mysteries I know of, and as far as your creepy psychological thrillers go, it ranks up there with the SAW series, and even with classics a SEVEN, THE SHINING, and THE SIXTH SENSE.And speaking of those classics, one staple of creepy psychological thrillers is the surprise ending, one that hits the audience so hard, that they will still be marveling at how well it was set up long after having seen it. The ending to THE NUMBER 23 is as shocking as receiving a punch in the face in a dark room.
summary: Possibly the most underrated movie of 2007

reviewText: I love Jim Carrey. He's the most versatile and gifted actor since Robin Williams. And I have enjoyed his forays into serious cinema such as Eternal Sunshine and Man on the Moon. But this first creepy and then idiotic caper ends up nowhere, and fast. Pink ties and mysterious biting dogs play a crucial role. Need I say more?It fancies itself a thrilling exploration of paranoia. The plot draws you in with its narrative style at first -- the film has to unfold at the pace with which Carrey's character reads a mysterious book he has received as a birthday present. Sadly, he's a slow reader.A somewhat similar but less sinister theme was recently seen in "Stranger Than Fiction", with another funnyman Will Ferrell finding a novel (being written contemporaneously) do the doozy on his psyche. I think that was in general a lot more successful, more thrilling, wittier.Number 23 on the other hand opts for a flawed sense of numerology as the conduit to its "24" like puerile thrills. Come on, even the most greenhorn numerology student will tell you that you cannot conveniently sum 14+9 and call it 23. A 14+9 is solved as 5+9, which adds up to 14, which is boiled down to 5. Not to 23.This addiction to 23, a kind of "discordianism", is well known and widely disregarded. Remember those post-911 chain mails that really reached to find oh-so-clever patterns in the number 911 and all that went with it? There's a lot one can find with such pattern-scouring obsessions if you care enough to google.But specious arithmetic is not the only thing going against this forgettable excuse for a film. It packs in several themes: occult, murder in a very black-and-white comic book style, and more gratuitous eroticism than seemed essential to me. Being surreal and dreamlike is one thing (especially in a manner that reeks of B-grade) but the elements add up so poorly that the story could have been concocted by a marginally talented chimpanzee.If it's any consolation, the music is excellent. I see it is now released as a CD. If you're a die-hard Jim Carrey fan, this film will not dent your impression of him too much. But for others, I recommend a pass. For Jim Carrey himself, a fresh sharp short haircut may be in order, such as the one seen in Me Myself and Irene.

reviewText: OK, so I was one of 23 people who actually liked The Number 23 when it came out on the big screen. Sue me for $23. And then double it, because although I will admit it's a bit flaccid upon second view, I still dug this semi-lurid Joel Schumacher / Jim Carrey fright flick (who, incidentally, worked together for the first time in 1994... 1+9+9+4 = 23) enough to recommend the DVD for anyone who likes conspiracy-driven psychological puzzlers.Carrey, also a producer (who named his production co. JC23 before signing on for this movie), plays Det. Fingerling a highly-sexed, risk-taking, boldly tattooed P.I. existing in a dark, deadly noir world where the women are fast and death comes even faster. His alter-ego -- or is it the other way around? -- is a quiet, gentle family man named Walter Sparrow (also Carrey), who finds himself straddling two worlds, each adding up to the number 23. As Fingerling and Walter try to solve the mystery of the noxious number, its inscrutability only deepens.Although there is only one disk, it's stuffed to its silver gills with additional release material. First of all, it's "Infinifilm" -- not sure what that is, but is sounds very impressive. (It basically means you can either watch the movie straight, or you can choose to veer off onto side roads of trivia and featurettes whenever you get the option to click away; once you've seen the extra bit, the movie resumes from where you left off.) The disk contains the theatrical release version of the movie, and a slightly sexier unrated version (the unrated version, for whatever reason, does not include  captions for the hearing-impaired).Needless to say, there are 23 scene selections. There are also 16 deleted scenes, plus an alternate ending. As far as additional release material goes, first up there's a basic making-of offering. Yet, it's more engaging than most, as it goes into the back story of the number 23 (first-time screenwriter Fernley Phillips based his story on the writings of Robert Anton Wilson... hm. My last name is Wilson, and I was born on the 23rd of the month...). It also reveals how and where the numbers are hidden (and overtly displayed) in the movie, has interviews with the stars and filmmakers, and behind the scenes footage.Another featurette is entitled Creating the World of Fingerling, and it begins with an overlong storyboard montage, then a look at some green screen footage, before finally delving into the goodies, which mostly concentrate on the cinematography (by Matthew Libatique, who also did Requiem for a Dream and The Fountain - not to mention two films previously for Schumacher). The filmmakers talk about the color palette, lighting design, and the joining of disparate worlds (i.e., the white-on-white of the Suicide Blonde's apartment to the cozy reds and russets of the Sparrow home). It does an eye-opening job of illustrating just how much most audiences take for granted when we watch a movie.There are two other featurettes which are more about the central riddle, and numerology (The Number 23 Enigma, and How to Find Your Life Path Number), plus an enthusiastic solo commentary by Schumacher. He has a gift of gab, which is welcome -- it not only feels like he talking to "you", but for those in search of real info, he imparts it: everything from who did the cool title sequence (Imaginary Forces) to the name of the canine actor (Butch). He also has a great memory for names and good enunciation (much appreciated, when one listens to as many DVD commentaries as I do).

reviewText: Usually when one comes across this film, their very first initial reaction is "Jim Carrey in a horror movie? Er..." Nevertheless they are still compelled to see it. As was I--but given the absolutely dreadful reviews "The Number 23" reeled in from distinguished film critics, I decided it wasn't worth my time and probably was just another lame excuse for a psychological horror film made in 2007. But today I decided, what the heck--we'll see if it's bad or good, as I paid a rough $4 at the Blockbuster counter to rent it.The Number 23 is a psychological horror film that deals with a man named Walter Sparrow (Carrey) whose wife gets him an old book entitled "The Number 23," which is about a sketchy detective named Fingerling who had a life filled with tragic loss, false love, murder, and above all, an unnatural obsession with the number 23. As Walter reads the book, he notices more and more striking similarities between him and the character, and it gets to the point where the number 23 becomes his central life figure as well, and slowly he believes he is transforming into the character that he thinks is a paper replica of himself.Pretty weak storyline, eh? Yeah, I thought so too. Fortunately the film keeps itself on its feet (sort of) through skilled directing and editing, decent acting, an eerie atmosphere, a well-written screenplay, and just the sheer excitement of watching Jim Carrey in a role that is completely polar opposite of Lloyd in "Dumb and Dumber." Some scenes are extremely intense and shocking in a good way, ways that'll make you pull the blanket up to your chin, and eagerly await what happens next.Other times you just want to go to bed. What is unfortunate about the movie is that the bad far outweighs the good. The decently-structured film is overrun and overkilled by extremely graphic and gratuitous sex scenes (75% of which really weren't necessary), laughably over-dramatic moments, and a ridiculously clichéd, washed-up "twist" that you didn't see coming because it's just so absurd in the first place. Many of the "freaky" references to the number 23 dealing with history are also factually incorrect.Overall, it is quite obvious this film was a failed attempt at being a remembered Hitchcock-style psychological horror film and while it was an entertaining watch, I can't help but feel cheated out of that $4 I spent today.I await the next great modern psychological horror film since "Saw."

reviewText: I'm not sure if it was the cold medicine I was on, which had numbers on the label that ironically added up together to make 23, but Joel Schumacher's latest cinematic endeavor almost won me over with its eccentric style. Too bad the story was so scatterbrained that when you calculate it all out `The Number 23' just doesn't add up.Admittedly the idea that a single number has the power to drive a man mad with its uncanny ability to almost infinitely attach itself to patterns certainly seems intriguing for a storyteller, especially a visually strong one like Schumacher. Love him or hate him for what he did to the Batman franchise, Schumacher has a knack for putting beautiful images on the big screen, and in `The Number 23' the director and `Requiem for a Dream' cinematographer Matthew Libatique put a visual exclamation point on this hauntingly beautiful descent into madness.While a director can pack as much style into a single frame as he or she wants, no matter how stunning the imagery is it still doesn't fix a flawed script, and `The Number 23' has as many plot holes as the title suggests. With `The Number 23' being screenwriter Fernley Philips' first screenplay produced into a major motion picture, one would think the writer would have put the time into tweaking the script's weaknesses, because the final product is a drawn-out mess.What are the serendipitous chances that Virginia Madsen's character just happens to pick up a book that will end up driving her husband mad? While Schumacher uses visually appealing, saturated color and basic principles of linear design to allow our sight to immediately be attracted to the novel, you still will find yourself asking why this book? When the convoluted and predictable finale hits, you too will be baffled over the slim twist of fate the `Number 23' revolves around.Perhaps the strongest selling point of `The Number 23' is for mainstream audiences to find out if Jim Carrey can handle a darker, dramatic role. While he already proved his acting chops in the pseudo romantic comedy `Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind', Carrey attempts to balance a unique mix between two characters, Fingerling, a film noir-like detective, and Walter Sparrow, who begins the film as your average pet detective (an inside joke perhaps?) that slowly succumbs his sanity to `The Number 23'.The most interesting parts of `The Number 23' take place within the picture's film noir sub story, which recreates the novel's account of Fingerling's murder mystery. These overexposed shots, which blast a surreal glow onto the brilliant lighting featured within each frame of Walter Sparrow's imaginative recreation of the novel, are far superior to the film's bland reality. Not only do the visuals pop off the screen, but Carrey and Madsen wrap their tongues around the hard boiled dialogue quite well, making the shoddy lines that comprise the rest of the picture all the more disappointing.While the use of style over substance in Schumacher's latest could have been forgiven had the film chosen to focus on the surreal, it is the belittling finale designed to tediously explain the plot for mass audiences that really made me cringe. I will admit, `The Number 23' had me for a while, but then the picture screeches to a halt to explain every minute detail for nearly a half an hour. Not only is it unnecessary, it is by far one of the longest debriefings ever featured in a motion picture.Though Schumacher certainly can be proclaimed as an expert stylist, his track record of misses certainly outweighs his hits. The reason is simple; Schumacher's films focus on style over substance. `The Number 23' is a prime example of this. I think even Joel Schumacher will appreciate the score this film received.-Joe Russo

reviewText: ...considering the lead actor is Jim Carrey.  The movie centers around Walter Sparrow, a typical working joe just trying to do his job.  On his birthday, which happens to be 02/03 (get it?), he encounters a dog that's just a little.....creepy.  He gets mauled, and this makes him late.  While he's saving the world from raging beasts, his wife Agatha, played by Virginia Madsen, is browsing a used bookstore, where she encounters the  book.  She buys it for him, and the obsession begins.As Walter reads this tome, he realizes, rather uncomfortably, that his life and the life of Fingerling, the main character in the book, dovetail very neatly.  Almost too neatly.  Walter soon believes that the author wrote the book about him and for him, to warn him of the insidiousness of the number 23.  Too late, though, as the number begins to take on exaggerated significance, almost to the point of insanity.  Soon Walter begins to believe he is just like Fingerling, and starts to dream of murdering his wife the same way Fingerling killed his sexy girlfriend.  When Walter believes he's figured out who wrote the book, his son and he set out to lure the man out of hiding, so they can confront him.  Agatha goes along to keep an eye on things, and to prove to Walter that there's nothing there.  Unfortunately, Dr. Serius Leary does walk into the trap (sensitively played by Bud Cort), and during the tussle, he cuts his own throat to escape the dreaded number.  Agatha stays with Leary to try and help, and sends Walter and son home.  She's there when Leary points her in a direction almost with his last, dying breath.  She calls Walter from the hospital, where Leary died, to tell him that there was nothing to know.  Then she goes across the street to the abandoned asylum Dr. Leary told her about.  There, she finds Walter's things, including the rough draft of the book, and the detective magazines that both he and Fingerling had been obsessed with since kids.Meanwhile, Walter has figured out the code of the book.  Every 23rd word on every 23rd page is a message to him, telling him where the body is buried.  He and Robin go and dig it up.  They call cops, but Agatha and her psychiatrist friend move it before cops can get there.  Walter confronts her, believing she was the one who wrote the book.  When she shows him his things from the asylum, he begins to remember that he was the one who wrote the book, and that he had actually killed the girl whose body he had just dug up.Though I'm making this sound rather simple and bland, it really isn't.  Jim Carrey showed depth of character and feeling I really didn't think him capable.  The flashback scene where he's pacing, writing the last chapter of his book over the hotel room walls, evoked Anthony Perkins for me.  I saw Norman Bates pacing there, trying to sort out the confusion in his head.  It was a genuinely suspenseful movie, and Carrey was very believeable as a suppressed psychopath.  There's natural, unexpressed rage in him, and he really shows that to the audience.  A very well-crafted film, and a good addition to Carrey's resume.

reviewText: When I saw the preview for NUMBER 23, I thought it was going to be a great film.  The concept of the number 23 being part of some global conspiracy is a great idea for a mystery thriller.  Also, Jim Carrey has done a great job of choosing roles that display the full range of his acting talents, not just ones that show his comic prowess and I was looking forward to seeing him in a mystery thriller film.  But instead of a mystery thriller, I saw a hacked up film that barely qualifies as a mystery, has no thrills, and very little suspense.Carrey portrays Walter Sparrow, and older man married to a younger woman named Agatha (Virginia Madsen) who works in a bakery.  Walter works as an animal control specialist.  Apparently Walter's job isn't all that exciting, but it is something he enjoys doing.  At the end of the work day on his birthday, he gets bitten by a stray dog.  He chases the dog until he looses him in a cemetery.  The incident causes Walter to be late meeting his wife for dinner, which leads her to browsing a used bookstore, where she finds a self-published book about the number 23 that she buys for Walter as a gift.  Apparently Walter was so late that Agatha was able to read the entire book while waiting for him.  Walter must be a slow reader because it takes him over a week before he finishes it at the end of which time he finds himself going slightly insane, seeing the number 23 everywhere he goes and having dreams about murdering his wife.  All reading and no play seems to make Walter a dull boy.  Is Walter really going insane?  Or is the book actually part of a larger story that Walter has become involved in?  Dum, dum, dum, dum, DUM! (Look what I did, onomatopoeia and foreshadowing combined!).I was really disappointed by NUMBER 23.  The concept is so interesting and could be made into a great movie, but NUMBER 23 isn't it.  Jim Carrey does a great job of playing both Walter Sparrow and the character of Fingerling from the novel, but he's not given much of a story to work with.  Either is the lovely Virginia Madsen.  She plays two roles, too, but neither has any real depth.  In fact, none of the characters are very developed at all.  Sometimes that's okay in a mystery suspense film, but not if you don't have much of a story to work with.I will give the filmmakers credit, though.  There are many people who will not like the ending of the film and even though I was disappointed, I'm glad they tried to bring closure to the whole story.  Many times in mystery-thriller and suspense the films end ambiguously with no closure.  As my parents used to say, "That's a dumb ending."  NUMBER 23 doesn't have a dumb ending.  Instead, it has a middle that doesn't make any sense.  I'd most like to see a film that makes sense all or at least most of the way through, but given a mindless middle or a dumb ending I think I would rather take the dumb ending.

reviewText: First of all, is this a drama? A thriller? A mystery? A wannabe film noir? A black comedy? It has elements of all these but something tells me it wasn't meant as a comedy! Jim Carrey's attempt at a "serious" movie didn't quite work out the way everyone hoped. I kept waiting for the big joke to come...the point when it became so ridiculous that I would burst out laughing going "Oh I get it!" and realize it all had one big hilarious punch line...But that didn't happen. By the end I was laughing because I was like, "Were they REALLY serious about this?" It wasn't so much that Jim was playing a serious role, so much as he looked like HE honestly wanted to laugh too.The plot pretty much goes in all crazy directions before finally leading you to a predictable ending. The final resolution makes sense but it is a little anti-climactic in my opinion. Jim Carrey plays Walter Sparrow, an animal control officer living a normal married life. Things take a turn for the worse when his wife Agatha (Virgina Madsen, she did a great job in the dual role as wife/femme fatale so the movie wins a star there) gives him a book for his birthday.The book "The Number 23" is about a detective named Fingerling who is cursed by...you guessed it...the number 23! (insert cheesy ominous music here) Soon Walter notices strange parallels between himself and the Fingerling character and are you ready for this?...The number 23 keeps popping up EVERYWHERE in Walter's life from his birthday to his address, his name...You get the idea. In fact he finds so many similarities between himself and this psycho, murdering Fingerling character that he is positive (gasp) "someone" who knows him well must have written it. Walter does find out who wrote the book but for anyone who is perceptive, it is pretty obvious early on.This WAS a pretty bad movie but certainly not the worst I have seen. I actually found it quite entertaining though I admit it was for all the wrong reasons! I have a warped sense of humor and I am a fan of "So bad they're good" movies. This wasn't bad enough to be good but I still had a few laughs. If you like to laugh at movies this does have potential. I would LOVE to see a Rifftrax made for this film!Anyone that could play this part with a straight face deserves some credit! Jim...you HAD to know this was bad, seriously! The Fingerling detective role was especially cheesy and laughable, almost like a comic book character. We also get to see a tattooed, freaky Jim Carey playing Fingerling and Virginia Madsen playing the femme fatale "Fabritzia" character (in a black wig) doing some crazy, stylized sex scenes.The movie did have a cool, creepy vibe and I liked the WAY it was filmed. This movie really didn't have to suck. It was a good idea and it probably had a decent budget, it was just poorly written and poorly executed. If it had a better plot this could have been a great movie. Personally, I think it would have been better with a crazier ending. It was a crazy, unrealistic movie so why should the ending make sense? The rest of it sure didn't! It had some gore, especially in the dream sequences but unless you find blood `shocking' you probably won't be frightened. They should have made it scarier. Numbers aren't scary...but wait...I WAS very torn on my rating. I could not decide if I wanted to give this a 2 or 3 star...2? 3? NOOOOO! The number 23 is after me!Anyway, rent this before you buy it for sure! Unless you are a die-hard Jim Carrey fan you probably won't like this. If you are a fan (like me) you might be entertained. I admit though it was more the fact that I was laughing AT the movie more than anything else! I am sure Jim Carrey was laughing all the way to the bank. Unfortunately in the case of this movie 2+3 does not= a 5 star movie, it mostly= A stinker! It is a somewhat funny stinker though...
